overrun.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to take more time or money than intended
overrun.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The final speaker overran by at least half an hour.
overrun.translation[0].definitions[1].de: if a place is overrun by unwanted things or people, they spread over it in great numbers
overrun.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: a tiny island overrun by tourists
The house was overrun with mice.
overrun.translation[0].definitions[1].no: Overrun is usually passive in this meaning
overrun.translation[0].definitions[2].de: if a place is overrun by soldiers, they take control of it
overrun.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Poland was overrun by the Russian army.
overrun.translation[0].definitions[2].no: Overrun is usually passive in this meaning
overrun.translation[1].definitions[0].de: an amount of time or money that is larger than was planned or intended
overrun.translation[2].definitions[0].de: an occasion when something costs more to develop and produce than was originally planned, or the amount of money involved in this
overrun.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: The Pentagon is expecting overruns of as much as $2.6 billion on its cargo plane program.
Almost from the start, the cost overruns were as staggering as the project itself.
overrun.translation[2].definitions[1].de: an extra quantity of things that is produced, which may not be needed
overrun.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to cost more or continue longer than expected or intended
overrun.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: The health service ended up subsidising the venture because the costs overran.
Businesses refused to commit themselves in case the project’s costs overran its budget.
